title: Cal Expo opens as shelter for people evacuating due to Oroville spillway concerns
text:
email Jim Eversole and his wife, Barbara, talk about their evacuation from the Oroville area to the Silver Dollar Fairgrounds in Chico on Monday, February 13, 2017. They were evacuated under threat of flooding after damage to the Oroville Dam spillway. Andy Furillo The Sacramento Bee Yuba City flood evacuees Roxanna Lyon,32, lends a kiss to son Wyatt, 3, as she balances daughter Laurie, 2, on her lap inside the Gurdwara Sahib Sikh Temple Sacramento on Monday, Feb., 13, 2017 in West Sacramento, Calif. The temple took in more than 200 people last night and this morning who were forced to evacuate the towns between Wheatland and Oroville while emergency crews tried to keep the Oroville Dam from flooding. Renee C. Byer rbyer@sacbee.com Inside the Gurdwara Sahib Sikh Temple Sacramento, Diljit Singh, 7, eats french fries, as his parents Ramandeep Kaur, left, and father, Baltwant Singh,49, center, rest after evacuating from Yuba City the night before on Monday, Feb., 13, 2017 in West Sacramento, Calif. Renee C. Byer rbyer@sacbee.com TJ Wallace, right, and Jacob Went walks past a homeless person sleeping on a bench along the Feather River on Monday, February 13, 2017 in Oroville, Calif. Oroville is under mandatory evacuation orders from the possible failure of the Oroville Dam spillway. Jose Luis Villegas jvillegas@sacbee.com Amrit Bal Singh, left, helps members of the Lyon family from Yuba City, who evacuated to the Gurdwara Sahib Sikh Temple in West Sacramento on Monday, Feb,13, 2017. The family including son Brian, 8, at right, mom Roxanna, 32, center holding Laurie, 2, and Wyatt, 3, dad Sam, 38, daughter Trinity, 9, and Sam's half brother Andrew Roy arrived Sunday evening and said they had not eaten since 4pm the previous day. Renee C. Byer rbyer@sacbee.com Amarjit Singh, second from right, helps distribute french fries to members of the Lyon family from Yuba City at the Gurdwara Sahib Sikh Temple Sacramento on Monday, Feb,13, 2017 in West Sacramento, Calif. The family including son Brian, 8, at left, mom Roxanna, 32, center, holding Laurie, 2, and Wyatt, 3, and daughter Trinity, 9, right, said they had not eaten since 4pm Sunday. Renee C. Byer rbyer@sacbee.com Gurbax Kaur Nagra, 70, center, her husband Malkiat Singh, right, said they were thankful for the Gurdwara Sahib Sikh Temple Sacramento on Monday, Feb,13, 2017 in West Sacramento, Calif. They evacuated from Yuba City on Sunday night and the temple provided them a place to sleep, blankets, pillows and food to eat. In the background is another family member Satwinder Kaur, 39. Renee C. Byer rbyer@sacbee.com Megan Sears and her son William, 10, leave their home that is next to the Feather river levee on Monday, February 13, 2017 in Oroville, Calif. they came home today to pick up a few more important belongings. Paul Kitagaki Jr. pkitagaki@sacbee.com 1 of 35 i 
By Ellen Garrison 
Cal Expo is open to residents from Yuba, Sutter and Butte counties who were evacuated Sunday night due to flooding concerns related to the Oroville Dam evacuation. 
The American Red Cross set up a shelter with assistance from the California Conservation Corps. Heath Wakelee, spokesman for the Red Cross’ Gold Country Region, said Cal Expo will take people in RVs as well. It opened at noon Monday. 
Supplies are pouring in from Los Angeles and Reno, Wakelee said. Five thousand cots, 10,000 blankets and 15,000 toiletry kits are on their way, he said. 
“This has been elevated now to a national event, so we have people flying in from all over the country with a lot of experience with large-scale events,” he said.
